newsitem.title: ITALY: BAA to take 65 pct stake in Naples airport.
newsitem.headline: BAA to take 65 pct stake in Naples airport.

text.p: British airport operator BAA Plc is set to take a 65 percent stake in Capodichino airport in Naples, the third biggest airport in Italy, a spokeswoman for the airport operator said on Wednesday.
She said the deal was expected to be signed in early March.
"Everything leads us to expect that the deal will go through," the spokeswoman for Gesac, the company which operates Capodichino told Reuters by telephone.
"The deal should be signed at the start of March," she said, adding that it would then be presented to Naples regional authorities for final approval.
In London, BAA said in a statement that negotiations to buy the controlling equity interest were "well-advanced" but it declined to confirm it was about to take a 65 percent stake.

BAA signed a non-binding letter of intent with Gesac last January. "If the signing of a conditional contract now goes ahead, completion will be subject to ohbtaining the relevant local approvals -- a process which could take up to 70 days," the statement said.
Under the new ownership structure, BAA would have a 65 percent stake and Naples local and provincial authorities would hold 20 percent plus a golden share, the Gesac spokeswoman said.
She said Italian flag carrier Alitalia would seek to keep its five percent share in Capodichino, Gesac staff would take a further five percent and private investors the balance.

The spokeswoman said she could not comment on the amount BAA was expected to pay but said that under a law on airport recapitalisation that linked investment to passenger numbers, Gesac's capital would be increased from 2.5 billion lire ($1.5 million) at present to some 25 billion lire ($15 million).
"BAA will take part in the capital increase," she said.
She said that a five-year "masterplan" for Capodichino, drawn up jointly by BAA and Gesac, foresaw investment of 240 billion lire ($145 million).
Naples airport handled nearly 2.9 million passengers in 1996 and is the third biggest airport in Italy behind Rome's Fiumicino and Milan's Linate, the spokeswoman said.
Aeroporti di Roma, the company which operates Rome's two airports, said it had sent a letter to Naples city officials saying it too was ready to take a stake in Gesac.
"ADR is ready to begin immediate talks to take a significant share stake in Gesac," the group said in a statement.

ADR said that as Italy's biggest airport operator, it had the professional, technical and financial resources to compete for a stake in Gesac but had not been contacted to see whether it would be willing to take part in the development plan.
It said such a move would be in line with its stated aim of extending its management activities to other airports.
The Gesac spokeswoman said ADR had expressed an interest in Naples when the BAA letter of intent was signed a year ago but "nothing came of it".
